right-middleOn the great variety of figures in composition.

22. Some seen from behind should show their heels,
some should sit, lie, crawl,
or climb, sink down, stand upright, kneel,
sometimes a few figures either fall down,
if appropriate, or stealthily creep,
some look upwards, lean, or crouch;
it is important to create a mixture
of clothed, half-clothed, and naked.
right-middleVarious movements of figures in composition.
right-middleOn the mingling of clothed and unclothed.

23. Many Composers also consider something
which I will not avoid and will stress,
to wit: that they should surround the true and
entire main point in their histories,
inscribed in a circle
so that a portion of the figures
surround the narrative, which as the center point
remains standing in the middle, such as a figure
which many behold or worship.
right-middleOn composing in a circle, with the central point in the middle.

24. But a composition can hardly be beautified,
according to my sense and my thinking,
by allowing only half the bodies of people,
horses, cattle, calves or other figures,
to appear in the frame, unless there is
a ground element that comes forward, made of stone
or something else, which suggests that
it is this which obscures the rest from view.
right-middle I write this with good intention, and not to scorn the great Masters who have not perceived this.

25. For artistic spirits will employ, as appropriate,
an abundance of buildings,
of horses, dogs, or other tame animals
or beasts, and birds of the forest;
but especially enjoyable to the eye are
fresh-faced youths and lovely young girls,
old men, matrons, all sorts
of children, older and younger.
